Yes, the Congregational Church has faced some challenges and controversies related to its progressive stance regarding the treatment of women and LGBTQ+ individuals.

One of the biggest controversies was when the church voted to allow the ordination of openly gay and lesbian ministers in 1985. This decision caused a rift within the denomination, with some churches and members leaving the United Church of Christ in protest.

Additionally, the church's stance on abortion has been a point of controversy. While the Congregational Church hasn't taken an official stance on the issue, some individual churches have taken a pro-choice stance, which has caused controversy within the denomination and with some members.

More recently, the Congregational Church has faced challenges related to diversity and racial justice. While the denomination has taken steps to promote diversity and inclusion, some members have called for more active efforts to combat systemic racism both within the church and in society.

Despite these challenges, the Congregational Church remains committed to its progressive values and to creating a more inclusive and just society.
